questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with fever, left-sided chest pain, and dyspnea. Upon physical examination, decreased breath sounds are noted on the left side. A chest X-ray reveals the findings presented below. A thoracentesis is performed, yielding a milky white fluid with elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and the presence of cholesterol crystals. Considering these findings, what underlying agent could be responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Type of Effusion

Mechanism

Fluid Appearance

Fluid Analysis Features

Pneumonia

Infection leading to inflammation

Straw-coloured or cloudy

High protein, high LDH

Empyema

Bacterial infection

Cloudy or turbid

Very high protein, very high LDH, low pH

Chylothorax

Lymphatic disruption

Milky or creamy

Elevated triglycerides, lymphocyte predominance

Pseudochylothorax

Chronic inflammation

Milky (but cholesterol-laden)

Cholesterol crystals, high lymphocytes

questions.text: Match the ABG values in Column A with their corresponding acid-base disorders in Column B. Column A Column B 1. pH 7.48, pCO2 45, HCO3 35 A. Fully compensated respiratory acidosis 2. pH 7.32, pCO2 28, HCO3 14 B. Partially compensated metabolic alkalosis 3. pH 7.40, pCO2 30, HCO3 20 C. Partially compensated metabolic acidosis 4. pH 7.38, pCO2 68, HCO3 32 D. Fully compensated respiratory alkalosis

A 35-year-old male presents with severe substernal chest pain, difficulty breathing, and puffy swelling of the chest wall after multiple episodes of vomiting due to binge drinking. Upon examination, auscultation reveals a characteristic crunching sound. A chest X-ray demonstrates the presence of subcutaneous emphysema. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the next best step in managing this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Obtain a CT scan of the chest

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department after experiencing sudden chest pain and shortness of breath. He is a long-time smoker with no history of lung disease. A chest X-ray confirms a right-sided pneumothorax. Which type of pneumothorax is this patient most likely experiencing?
questions.explanation:
Type of Pneumothorax

Cause

Characteristics

Common Treatment

Primary Spontaneous Pneumothorax

Occurs without underlying lung disease
  • Often due to rupture of apical pleural blebs
  • Seen commonly in smokers
  • Simple aspiration
  • Thoracoscopy if recurrent

Secondary Spontaneous Pneumothorax (Option A)

Associated with pre-existing lung conditions (e.g., COPD)

More life-threatening due to reduced pulmonary reserve
  • Tube thoracostomy
  • Thoracoscopy or pleurodesis if needed
  • Thoracoscopy with stapling of blebs and pleural abrasion if surgery is contraindicated

Traumatic Pneumothorax (Option B)

Occurs during mechanical ventilation or resuscitation

Can be iatrogenic (from medical procedures)
  • Tube thoracostomy
  • Manage hemopneumothorax with dual chest tubes

Tension Pneumothorax (Option D)

Results from physical injury (blunt or penetrating)
  • Positive pressure in pleural space
  • Severe cardiovascular compromise

Emergency treatment with large bore needle decompression followed by thoracostomy

questions.text: A 55-year-old female with a history of COPD presents to the emergency department with sudden onset left-sided chest pain. A chest X-ray reveals a small left-sided pneumothorax with a depth of 0.5 cm. The patient is otherwise stable, with no significant respiratory distress and a normal vital sign profile. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer high-flow oxygen and observe for 24 hours

questions.correct_answer: A. Administer high-flow oxygen and observe for 24 hours

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a motorcycle accident. He is experiencing severe shortness of breath and sharp left-sided chest pain. On examination, he has tachycardia and low oxygen saturation. A chest X-ray confirms a large left-sided pneumothorax. Vitals are HR: 120 bpm, BP: 70/40. What would be the most appropriate first step in the management of this patient?
A patient with chest pain and shortness of breath with a heart rate of 145 beats per minute is being examined in the casualty. Which of the following clinical features is not seen in a pneumothorax?

A child was brought to the hospital with noticeable difficulty in breathing. On examination, he has tachycardia, tachypnea, and asymmetrical lung expansion. A supine chest X-ray is taken and shown below. Identify the marked sign/structure in this patient's chest radiograph.
questions.explanation:
Radiological Findings in Pneumothorax

  • Visible visceral pleural edge as a thin white line. (Option B)
  • Absent lung markings peripheral to this line.
  • The affected side is radiolucent compared to the opposite side.
  • Collapsed lung on the affected side. (Option A)
 Pneumothorax collapsed lung" data-author="" data-hash="9509" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/tTT8sqheLKI5OoK9eLF51744387538.jpg" />

Contralateral mediastinal shift especially in massive pneumothoraces (tension pneumothorax).

 Pneumothorax Contralateral mediastinal shift" data-author="" data-hash="9513" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/WcbkJiqgXlPMQgP51jxl1744387674.jpg" />

The diaphragm of the affected side is pushed down. (Option C)

 Pneumothorax Diaphragm pushed down" data-author="" data-hash="9515" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/ctfGHM5QgvPxMYsRkdmj1744387863.jpg" />
  • The supine radiograph shows the deep sulcus sign.
  • It shows a deep costophrenic angle extending towards the hypochondrium.
 sulcus sign" data-author="" data-hash="9500" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/ddeXhvz2apaPcQiaMs3V1744387096.png" />

Light’s Index

Light’s Criteria

  • It is used to measure the size of pneumothorax.
  • Treatment approaches for primary spontaneous pneumothorax (PTX) are influenced by the size of the pneumothorax.
  • Light’s criteria is used to identify exudates from transudates in pleural effusions.
  • An effusion is classified as an exudate if it meets any of the following criteria:
    • A pleural-to-serum protein ratio >0.5
    • A pleural-to-serum lactate dehydrogenase ratio >0.6
    • A pleural lactate dehydrogenase level greater than two-thirds of the upper limit of normal for serum.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male comes to the emergency department after a fall from height. He developed shortness of breath, tachypnea, and chest pain since the fall. A chest X-ray was taken shown below. What would be the pathophysiology for the development of this condition?
questions.correct_answer: C. Blunt trauma to the chest

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding normal pleural fluid characteristics is accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Normal pleural fluid typically contains over 3,000 WBCs/mm³.

options.label: B
options.text: The glucose level in normal pleural fluid is typically lower than that of plasma.

options.label: C
options.text: Normal pleural fluid pH ranges from 7.60 to 7.64.

options.label: D
options.text: Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels in normal pleural fluid are similar to those in plasma.

questions.correct_answer: C. Normal pleural fluid pH ranges from 7.60 to 7.64.
questions.explanation:
Pleural anatomy

Normal pleural fluid characteristics
  • Appearance: Clear ultrafiltrate of plasma from the parietal pleura.
  • pH Level: Ranges from 7.60 to 7.64. (Option C)
  • Protein Content: Less than 2% (1-2 g/dL).
  • White Blood Cells: Fewer than 1,000 WBCs per cubic millimetre. (Option A ruled out)
  • Glucose Level: Comparable to that of plasma. (Option B ruled out)
  • Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH): Less than 50% of plasma levels. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with Parkinson's disease has been experiencing fluctuations in his motor function, To help manage these "on-off" features, new medication to his treatment regimen. However, the patient later presented with respiratory distress, chest discomfort, and diminished breath sounds on examination. Which medication is likely to be the possible cause of these respiratory symptoms?
questions.explanation:
• Pneumonia (Parapneumonic Effusion)
  • Empyema
  • Malignancy
  • Chylothorax
  • Pseudochylothorax
  • Autoimmune Diseases
  • Drug-Induced Effusions
  • Amiodarone
  • Methotrexate
  • Nitrofurantoin
  • Dantrolene
  • Hydralazine
  • Bromocriptine (Option C)

questions.text: A 55-year-old male who has worked in the shipyard industry presents with shortness of breath and persistent pain in the right lower chest. On examination, there is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds on the right side. A CT scan reveals diffuse pleural thickening and nodular masses. A biopsy is performed to confirm the diagnosis. Which immunohistochemical marker is most likely to be positive?
questions.explanation:
Symptoms

Signs

Early symptoms:

  • Chest pain
  • Shortness of breath (dyspnea)
  • Pleural effusion (fluid buildup in the pleural space)

Progressive symptoms:

  • Chronic cough
  • Weight loss
  • Fatigue
  • Decreased breath sounds
  • Dullness to percussion
  • Pleural thickening

Immunohistochemical Marker

Associated Diseases

HER2/neu

Breast cancer, Gastric cancer

CD20

B-cell lymphomas, (Pre-B cells express CD19 and mature into B cells, but not plasma cells)

CD3

T-cell lymphomas

CD68

Histiocytic lesions, Macrophages

CK7

Lung adenocarcinoma, Ovarian cancer

CK20

Colorectal cancer, Merkel cell carcinoma

S100

Melanoma, Schwannoma, LCH

GFAP

Astrocytomas, Gliomas

PSA

Prostate cancer

TTF-1

Lung adenocarcinoma

Vimentin

Sarcomas, Endometrial cancer

p53

Various cancers (e.g., Colon, Breast)

ER/PR

Breast cancer

Ki-67

Proliferation marker in many tumours

CD117 (c-kit)

Gastrointestinal stromal tumours (GIST)

HMB-45

Melanoma

Synaptophysin

Neuroendocrine tumors

Chromogranin

Neuroendocrine tumors

ALP

Bone-forming tumours

Desmin

Muscle tumours (e.g., Rhabdomyosarcoma)

questions.text: A 63-year-old female with metastatic adenocarcinoma of the lung presents with worsening dyspnea and a moderate-sized left-sided pleural effusion. After therapeutic thoracentesis reveals exudative fluid with low glucose levels and positive cytology for malignant cells, her symptoms improve, but the effusion is expected to reaccumulate. What is the most appropriate next step for long-term symptomatic relief?

options.label: A
options.text: Insertion of a small indwelling pleural catheter

options.label: C
options.text: Tube thoracostomy without a sclerosing agent

options.label: D
options.text: Initiation of diuretics and oxygen therapy

questions.correct_answer: A. Insertion of a small indwelling pleural catheter
questions.explanation:
Malignant Pleural Effusion

Prevalence

Second most common cause of exudative pleural effusion.

Common Cancers

Lung carcinoma, breast carcinoma, and lymphoma (responsible for ~75% of cases).

Primary Symptom

Dyspnea, which is often disproportionate to the size of the effusion.

Fluid Characteristics

Exudative pleural fluid with possible reduced glucose levels in cases of high tumour burden.


 

Diagnosis
  • Cytology of pleural fluid (initial step).
  • Thoracoscopy: If cytology is -ve & malignancy is suspected, thoracoscopy is the next step, often paired with pleurodesis via pleural abrasion.
  • Alternative Biopsy: If thoracoscopy is not feasible, a CT- or ultrasound-guided needle biopsy of pleural thickening or nodules can be performed.


 

Treatment

  • Treatment is mostly symptomatic, as pleural effusions indicate disseminated disease and curative chemotherapy is generally not possible.
  • If dyspnea impairs the patient’s quality of life and is relieved by therapeutic thoracentesis, further interventions include:
  • Insertion of a small indwelling catheter. (Option A)
  • Tube thoracostomy with a sclerosing agent (e.g., doxycycline 500 mg). (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A resident physician is preparing to perform a thoracentesis on a patient with a large pleural effusion. The patient is seated, and the procedure is to be performed under ultrasound guidance. Which of the following steps is crucial for the correct execution of the thoracentesis procedure?

options.label: A
options.text: Insert the needle below the lower rib to avoid injury

options.label: B
options.text: Perform the procedure at the 2nd intercostal space in the midclavicular line

options.label: C
options.text: Ensure the patient is in a supine position for optimal access

options.label: D
options.text: Insert the needle above the upper border of the lower rib in the targeted intercostal space

questions.correct_answer: D. Insert the needle above the upper border of the lower rib in the targeted intercostal space
questions.explanation:
Thoracentesis

 

Indications
  • Diagnostic: Unexplained effusions, suspected infections or malignancies, differentiation of cardiac vs. noncardiac causes.
  • Therapeutic: Symptomatic relief in large effusions, pleurodesis preparation, empyema drainage, fluid reaccumulation (e.g., traumatic hemothorax).
  • Dual Role: Parapneumonic effusions may require both diagnostic and therapeutic thoracentesis to prevent complications and improve outcomes.

Contraindications
  • Absolute: Bleeding disorders, active infection at the puncture site.
  • Relative: Mechanical ventilation, severe hemodynamic instability, previous infections or surgeries causing adhesions (may limit fluid removal).

Procedure
  • Conducted in a sterile environment, the procedure is usually carried out between the 6th & 8th intercostal spaces (Option B), targeting the midaxillary line for supine patients and the posterior mid-scapular line for those seated.
  • The needle is being put above the upper border of the lower rib. (Option A)
  • Guidance: Ultrasound-guided for improved accuracy and safety.
  • Steps: Skin prep → local anaesthesia → catheter insertion → fluid drainage for diagnosis or relief.

Complications

Bleeding, infection, pneumothorax, post-expansion pulmonary oedema (if rapid fluid removal).

Pneumothorax risk is higher in ventilated patients; and may require chest tube placement.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with shortness of breath and cough. Chest X-ray shows a left-sided pleural effusion. Thoracentesis reveals the following findings. Using Light's criteria, which statement is true regarding this pleural effusion? Pleural fluid protein: 4.0 g/dL Serum protein: 6.8 g/dL Pleural fluid LDH: 280 U/L Serum LDH: 450 U/L

options.label: B
options.text: It meets the criteria for an exudative effusion.

options.label: C
options.text: It cannot be classified without further testing.

options.label: D
options.text: It is likely due to congestive heart failure.

questions.correct_answer: B. It meets the criteria for an exudative effusion.
questions.explanation:
Radiological Investigation

X-ray:

  • 200 mL of fluid is needed for detection on the posteroanterior (PA) view.
  • 50 mL of fluid may lead to blunting of the costophrenic angle on the lateral view.
  • A homogeneous opacity with obliteration of the costophrenic angle is typical.
  • This appearance is marked by a curved upper border, known as the Ellis S-shaped curve.
  • Obliteration of cardiophrenic angle.

Ultrasound: More effective than X-ray in detecting fluid presence, showing a clear hypoechoic space indicative of transudate and moving densities suggesting exudate.

Pleural Fluid Analysis

Light's Criteria

Differentiates transudative from exudative pleural effusions based on LDH and protein levels in pleural fluid.

  • An exudative pleural effusion meets at least one of the following:
    1. Pleural fluid protein/serum protein > 0.5
    2. Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH > 0.6
    3. Pleural fluid LDH exceeds two-thirds of the normal upper limit for serum.
  • ~25% of transudates may be misidentified as exudates.
  • If exudative criteria are met but a transudative condition is suspected, measure protein difference; if >31 g/L (3.1 g/dL), likely transudative.

Additional Tests for Exudative Effusions
  • Appearance description
  • Glucose level
  • Differential cell count
  • Microbiologic studies
  • Cytology

If Glucose <60 mg/dL Consider:

  • Malignancy
  • Bacterial infections (empyema)
  • Rheumatoid pleuritis

Standard Peculiarities

  • Heart Failure: NT-proBNP level > 1500 pg/mL indicates effusion due to congestive heart failure
  • Parapneumonic Effusion: Key criteria include:
  • Loculated pleural fluid
  • Pleural fluid pH < 7.20
  • Pleural fluid glucose < 3.3 mmol/L (< 60 mg/dL)
  • Positive Gram stain or culture results
  • Presence of visible pus
  • Tuberculous Pleuritis: Diagnosis confirmed by high TB markers in pleural fluid (adenosine deaminase > 40 IU/L or interferon γ > 140 pg/mL)

questions.text: A 60-year-old female with a known diagnosis of metastatic mesothelioma presents with worsening dyspnea and right-sided chest pain that is constant. Chest imaging is given below. What clinical finding is most likely to be present?

options.label: B
options.text: Egophony at the superior aspect of the effusion

options.label: D
options.text: Bronchial breath sounds over the effusion

questions.correct_answer: B. Egophony at the superior aspect of the effusion
questions.explanation:
Clinical findings of Pleural effusion

Symptoms
  • Cough, fever, and systemic signs depending on the underlying cause.
  • Pleurisy, marked by sharp, localized pain during breathing or coughing, occurs with active pleural inflammation but typically subsides once the effusion forms.
  • Constant pain, however, is often associated with malignant conditions like mesothelioma.

Physical Examination
  • Dullness on percussion. (Option A ruled out)
  • Decreased breath sounds. (Option D ruled out)
  • Diminished tactile and vocal fremitus. (Option C ruled out)
  • Egophony is most pronounced at the upper part of the effusion. (Option B)
  • Pleural Rubs can be heard during active pleurisy and may be confused with coarse crackles.

History and Diagnostic Focus
  • Comprehensive history to explore potential causes of pulmonary and systemic effusions.
  • Assess for comorbidities, medications, infectious disease indicators, and malignancy risk factors.
  • Congestive Heart Failure: Suspected with jugular venous distension, S3 heart sound, and pedal oedema.
  • Liver Cirrhosis: Considered with signs such as ascites and caput medusae.
  • Primary TB: Cachexia, cough, hemoptysis, extreme breathlessness, night sweats, evening rise in temperature.

questions.text: A patient presents with dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain. A chest X-ray shows a pleural effusion. Pleural fluid analysis reveals elevated protein and LDH levels. Which of the following conditions is the likely cause of this exudative pleural effusion?
questions.explanation:
Causes of pleural effusion

Tranudative

Exudative

Both
  • Congestive heart failure (Option C)
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome (Option D)
  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • SVC obstruction
  • Myxedema
  • Urinothorax (Option A)
  • Malignancies
  • Tuberculosis
  • Pneumonia
  • Esophageal perforation (Option B)
  • Pancreatic disease
  • Collagen vascular diseases:
  • Rheumatoid pleuritis
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Sjögren syndrome
  • Wegener Granulomatosis

Pulmonary embolism

Drugs induced
  • Nitrofurantoin
  • Dantrolene
  • Methysergide
  • Bromocriptine
  • Procarbazine
  • Amiodarone
  • Dasatinib
